back: For a sample space $S$ and a probability measure $P,$ the event class, denoted by $\mathcal{F}$ is a collection of all subsets of $S$ to which we will assign probability (i.e., for which $P$ will be defined). The sets in $\mathcal{F}$ are called events.
For a set $S$ with finite cardinality, $|S|=N < \infty$, the power set is the set of all possible subsets. We will use the notation $2^S$ to denote the power set.
The probability measure, $P$, is a real-valued set function that maps every element of the event class to the real line.
A composite experiment is any experiment that consists of multiple sub-experiments.
A trial in a compound experiment is one of the sub-experiments that make up the composite experiment.
A repeated experiment is a compound experiment in which the trials are identical and independent of each other.
An experiment has statistical regularity if under repeated experiments, the relative frequencies converge (in some sense) to some fixed values.
An outcome of a random experiment is a result of the experiment that cannot be further decomposed.
The sample space of a random experiment is the set of all possible outcomes.
An event is a set of outcomes. The event occurs if the result of the experiment is any of the outcomes in the set.
An experiment is said to be fair if every outcome is equally likely.

The _cartesian product_ of two sets $A$ and $B$ is denoted $A \times B$ and is defined by 

$$A \times B = \{ (a,b) | a \in A \mbox{ and } b \in B\}.
$$
That is, it is the set of all two-tuples with the first element from set $A$ and the second element from set $B$.
A *permutation* is an ordering (or reordering) of a set of objects.
